instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b problems sleep
threads.message:
good this team goes to sleep and does not leave this, it's time to turn it on again

I have already changed the battery led indicator card, problem persists; I don't know what measures to take for this problem, thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b problems sleep
threads.message:
Do PRAM reset 2-3 times.

<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> steady high after open lid?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b problems sleep
threads.message:
reset pram resete 2-3 times same problem
yes, after open lid, <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 3.3V steady

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b problems sleep
threads.message:
Discard software issue.
Test with USB macOS, or other HDD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b problems sleep
threads.message: with another disk and a good operating system the same problem happens

This also helps to discard a software problem.
